author: johnthepro
body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

I've installed PowerShell 7.2 via the MSSTORE.

I've noticed that when spawning a pwsh terminal, if I run ```Get-ExecutionPolicy -List``` the Process policy is 'Bypass' by default.

Is this expected behavior? I'd imagine not, as it seems to present an opportunity to circumvent the system's ExecutionPolicy.


### Expected behavior

```console
Described above.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Described above.
```


### Error details

```console
No error returned.
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.0
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22504
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45504030/144103430-88fe7dbc-e0ca-4abb-a7e2-a7d7f8b34349.png)

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
There is no default process Execution policy. It's set when you run `pwsh -executionPolicy <something>` or if you have set the  PSExecutionPolicyPreference environment variable. 
Silly question, in Windows Terminal, if you go to settings and select PowerShell under profiles, does the command-line there set the execution policy?   
If you run pwsh outside of terminal (e.g. run cmd, and do a SET to check for PSExecutionPolicyPreference) what do you get ?

comments.author: johnthepro
comments.body:
No, no such modification inside the Command Line section of the PowerShell 7 profile in Windows Terminal.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45504030/144120619-ef6da6fb-d7d9-42cc-8878-1d26c49b7171.png)

If I run pwsh from cmd first, the policy for the process is still Bypass.
Sorry, not sure what you meant by 'do a SET to check for PSExecutionPolicyPreference'

comments.author: johnthepro
comments.body:
I did also just notice that I have 'PowerShell' and 'PowerShell 7' - I have both the "winget" sourced version installed, as well as the version from the MSSTORE.

Neither one has command line options that set the ExecutionPolicy.
Both of them have a Process ExecutionPolicy of Bypass, simply after spawning their respective shell prompts.

**UPDATE**
I uninstalled the 'winget' version to better align my environment with the reported issue.
MSSTORE version of 7.2 is only pwsh installed now.

comments.author: johnthepro
comments.body:
> If I run pwsh from cmd first, the policy for the process is still Bypass. Sorry, not sure what you meant by 'do a SET to check for PSExecutionPolicyPreference'

I figured out what you meant. Sorry, long day. That variable isn't present when running SET via cmd.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45504030/144184202-311d3643-defb-4828-b471-8223999b3167.png)

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body: OK, well that's not expected behaviour, and we've crossed the two most obvious causes off the list.  Time for someone with more expertise about how the install process works  to take over ...

comments.author: johnthepro
comments.body: Happy to provide any information necessary!

comments.author: PaulHigin
johnthepro
comments.body:
Thanks for the reply! As far as 'how' it's launched, well, usually from Windows Terminal on my Taskbar. But it doesn't much seem to matter; Windows Terminal, cmd, a windows PowerShell process; I run pwsh.exe, I end up with the Execution Policy as detailed in the image.

To create this image, just now, I started a user level 'cmd' process, and called `pwsh.exe -noprofile` from it. I then ran `Get-ExecutionPolicy -list` and the results are the same. Process level is bypass. After that, I exited the 'pwsh' process, and started a 'powershell' process and ran `Get-ExecutionPolicy -list` just to show the difference, should it be relevant.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45504030/145899544-796eec4b-e5d8-48f1-a92a-dea7fc35fa78.png)

Where might I go to figure out what might be doing it?

comments.author: johnthepro
comments.body: Thought you'd like to know that this 'issue' persists into PowerShell 7.2.1 and the latest version of Windows Terminal (1.11.3471)

comments.author: PaulHigin
comments.body:
@johnthepro the Process scope ExecutionPolicy is stored and retrieved in the `PSExecutionPolicyPreference` process target environment variable.  A new process will pick up this environment variable setting from its parent.

I am able to repro this, but only by setting a machine wide environment variable:
`PSExecutionPolicyPreference = Bypass`
and then starting a cmd.exe shell and running `pwsh.exe -noprofile`.
The `PSExecutionPolicyPreference` environment variable appears in the pwsh session in `Process` target and so execution policy is set to `bypass` in that session.

I suspect that if you looked for `PSExectuionPolicyPreference` variable in your cmd.exe process you will see it set to `bypass`:

```powershell
C:\>echo %PSExecutionPolicyPreference%
Bypass
```

comments.author: johnthepro
comments.body:
I'm beginning to wonder if SentinelOne has anything to do with this. I have a laptop that doesn't have it on it that I can check.

I've provided a screenshot of my Environment Variables. I don't have a machine-wide environment variable for PSExecutionPolicyPreference.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45504030/156315431-2664a621-8f81-4ab5-bb6b-8283da6b93fb.png)

comments.author: mhkline
comments.body:
I have this same issue. Powershell 7.2.1 and 7.2.2 default to Bypass execution policy, and Get-ExecutionPolicy -List displays Bypass as the process execution policy.

> I don't have a machine-wide environment variable for PSExecutionPolicyPreference.

Same. I still have Powershell 5 installed, and it doesn't have this issue.

> I'm beginning to wonder if SentinelOne has anything to do with this.

FWIW, my system also has SentinelOne installed.

comments.author: johnthepro
comments.body:
I'll have to break out the laptop this evening then and check that config versus this one here. Thanks for providing some additional insight!

It's nice to not be the only one with a problem!

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45504030/159752598-269a9c31-378c-4c54-ba72-89cdbc9b3cc4.png)

comments.author: ZamElek
comments.body: Have the same issue and also BTW have SentinelOne antivirus...

comments.author: ZamElek
comments.body: We tested and found out that the problem occurs after installing Sentinel One and rebooting the device. There is no such problem in a clean Windows OS. We have opened a ticket for Sentinel One.

title: PWSH 7.2 potential issue with default process ExecutionPolicy
